Curriculum Vitae
July 2015
163 Nassau Rd.
Huntington, NY 11743
Department of Sociology & Anthropology
720 Northern Blvd.
Brookville, NY 11548
jennifer.brown@liu.edu
EDUCATION
Ph.D. Department of Sociology. Doctoral emphasis in Women's Studies and Certificate in College
and University Teaching (CCUT). University of California, Santa Barbara. 2008.
M.A. Department of Sociology, University of California, Santa Barbara. Honors Pass, 2005.
B.A. Department of Sociology and Women’s Studies, University of California, Irvine. 2001.
PROFESSIONAL EXPERIENCE
2010-Present Assistant Professor. Department of Sociology and Anthropology. Long Island
University, Post.
Postdoctoral Fellow. NSF Nanoscale Science and Engineering Center: Center for
Nanotechnology in Society, University of CA, Santa Barbara. Affiliation with
Feminist Studies Department.
PUBLICATIONS
Refereed Journal Articles
2013 Shearer, Christine, Jennifer Rogers-Brown, Karl Bryant, Rachel Cranfill, and Barbara Herr
Harthorn. “Power and Vulnerability: Recontextualizing ‘Low-risk’ Views of Environmental
and Health Hazards.” Research in Social Problems and Public Policy 21.
2011 Rogers, Jennifer. “Radio and Collective Identity in the 2006 Oaxacan Uprising.”
2011 Rogers-Brown, Jennifer, Christine Shearer, and Barbara Herr Harthorn. “From Biotech to
Spaces for Difference: An Interdisciplinary Journal. 2(2).
Nanotech: Public Debates about Technological Modification of Food.” Environment &
Society 2.
Book Chapters
2015 Rogers-Brown, Jennifer. “More than a War Story: A Feminist Analysis of Doing Dangerous
Fieldwork.” In At the Center: Feminism, Social Science and Knowledge (Advances in Gender
Research, Volume 20). Eds. Vasilikie Demos and Marcia Texler Segal. Emerald Group
Publishing Limited.
2014 Rogers-Brown, Jennifer. “The Gendered Ma(i)ze of Globalization.” In Feminisms and
Ruralities. Eds. Barbara Pini, Berit Brandth, and Jo Little. Lexington Books.
2012 Rogers-Brown, Jennifer, Christine Shearer, and Barbara Herr Harthorn. “Different Uses,
Different Responses: Exploring Emergent Cultural Values through Public Deliberation.” In
The Social Life of Nanotechnology. Eds. Barbara Herr Harthorn and John Mohr. Routledge.
2012 Rogers-Brown, Jennifer and Amy Zader. “Food Security: From the Green Revolution to
Nanotechnology.” In Can Technologies Make a Difference in Development? Eds. Rachel
Parker and Richard Appelbaum. Routledge.
2012 Harthorn, Barbara Herr, Christine Shearer, and Jennifer Rogers-Brown. “Risk
Perception, Public Participation, and Sustainable Global Development of Nanotechnologies,”
In Can Technologies Make a Difference in Development? Eds. Rachel Parker and Richard
Appelbaum. Routledge.
2011 Rogers, Jennifer. “Maíz y País: Indigenous Mexican Struggles against Biotechnology in
Agriculture.” In Cultural Politics in the 21st Century: Global Resistance and Community
based Social Movements in the Americas. Eds. Kara Dellacioppa and Clare Weber. Palgrave
Macmillan.
2011 Harthorn, Barbara Herr, Jennifer Rogers, and Christine Shearer. “Debating Nanoethics: US
Public Perceptions of Nanotech Applications for Energy and Environment.” In Debating
Science: Deliberation, Values, and the Common Good. Ed. Dane Scott. Humanity Books.
2011 Harthorn, Barbara Herr, Christine Shearer, and Jennifer Rogers. “Exploring ambivalence:
Techno-enthusiasm and skepticism in US nanotech deliberations.” In Quantum
Engagements: Social Reflections of Nanoscience and Emerging Technologies. Ed. Torben B.
Zülsdorf, Christopher Coenen, Arianna Ferrari, Ulrich Fiedeler, Colin Milburn, & Matthias
Wienroth. Amsterdam: IOS Press.
2002 Ariel, Joan and Jennifer Rogers. “Resources: Reference Guides, Videos, and
Websites for Teaching Feminist Activism” in Teaching Feminist Activism: Strategies from
the Field. Eds. Nancy A. Naples and Karen Bojar. New York: Routledge, 272-308.
Conference Proceedings
2010 Harthorn, Barbara Herr, Jennifer Rogers, and Christine Shearer. Gender, application
domain, and ethical dilemmas in nano-deliberation. White paper for Nanotech Risk
Perception Specialist Meeting, Santa Barbara, Jan 29-30.
2009 Harthorn, Barbara Herr, Karl Bryant, and Jennifer Rogers. “Gendered Risk Beliefs
about Emerging Technologies in the US,” Univ of Washington Center for Workforce
Development; on-line publication posted at
http://depts.washington.edu/ntethics/symposium/index.shtml.

of Nanoscience and Society. Eds. David Guston and J. Geoffrey Golson. Sage Publications.

(Summer 2007)

Introduction to Sociology; Research Methods; Social Movements; Contemporary U.S. Women’s
Movements; Sociology and Sexual Politics; Sociology of Lesbian and Gay Communities; Women
in American Society; Theories of Gender and Inequality; Women, Society, and Culture; Women
and Development; Women, Representation, and Cultural Production; Modern Sex and Modern
Love
RESEARCH EXPERIENCE
Research Assistant for Professor Jennifer Earl. UC Santa Barbara.
Provided research assistant support on various projects, including Professor Earl’s
research on online vote trading during the 2004 presidential election.

Peer Review
The Social Science Journal. 2012-2013.

2006 No Alibis. KCSB Radio. Interview regarding APPO and the 2006 Oaxaca conflict.
